greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of distinct anagrams of digits of n without leading zeros.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: a(101)=2 since the digits of 101 can be ordered 101 or 110 (but not 011)
mathematica: a[n_] := Length[ DeleteCases[ Permutations[ IntegerDigits[n]], {0 .., __}]]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 102}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Nov 30 2011 *)
program: a055098 n = length $ nub $ filter ((> '0') . head) $ permutations $ show n
(PARI) a(n)={my(v=digits(n), f=vector(10), n=#v); for(i=1, #v, f[1+v[i]]++); (1 - f[1]/n) * n! / prod(i=1, #f, f[i]!)} \\ _Andrew Howroyd_, Jan 27 2020
results.author: _Henry Bottomley_, Apr 19 2000
